docs.abstract: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
docs.snippet: Steve Jobs said Apple was 90 days from bankruptcy in 1997. Now it is the first publicly traded American company to be worth $1 trillion.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 1997, Apple was on the ropes. The Silicon Valley pioneer was being decimated by Microsoft and its many partners in the personal-computer market. It had just cut a third of its work force, and it was about 90 days from going broke, Apple’s late co-founder, Steve Jobs, later said.

headline.main: Apple Is Worth $1,000,000,000,000. Two Decades Ago, It Was Almost Bankrupt.
headline.print_headline: Apple Is Worth $1 Trillion; 21 Years Ago It Was on the Brink of Bankruptcy

docs.abstract: Two college students in Oregon are accused of tricking Apple into replacing nearly 1,500 counterfeit iPhones with genuine ones that were later sold.
docs.snippet: Two college students in Oregon are accused of tricking Apple into replacing nearly 1,500 counterfeit iPhones with genuine ones that were later sold.
docs.lead_paragraph: The con was simple: Send a fake iPhone to Apple claiming that the device would not turn on and that it was under warranty, and not long after, a genuine replacement arrived in the mail.

headline.main: Scheme to Swap Fake iPhones Adds Up to $900,000 Loss for Apple, Prosecutors Say
headline.print_headline: Apple Loses $900,000 To Fake iPhone Swaps

docs.abstract: In Apple v. Pepper, the Supreme Court will decide whether iPhone App Store customers are entitled to make their case against the tech giant.
docs.snippet: In Apple v. Pepper, the Supreme Court will decide whether iPhone App Store customers are entitled to make their case against the tech giant.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Nov. 26, the Department of Justice argued before the Supreme Court in the case Apple v. Pepper, that the millions of us who have bought iPhone applications through Apple’s App Store — the only way the company offers to buy an app for the device — are not really Apple’s customers.

headline.main: You Should Have the Right to Sue Apple

docs.abstract: America’s global dominance in technology requires fierce competition at home, not the coddling of monopolies.
docs.snippet: America’s global dominance in technology requires fierce competition at home, not the coddling of monopolies.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last year or so, Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook and other American tech leaders have issued a stark warning to those who want to see more competition in the industry. It goes something like this: “We understand that we’ve made mistakes. But don’t you realize that if you damage us, you’ll just be handing over the future to China? Unlike America, China is standing behind its tech firms, because it knows that the competition is global, and it wants to win.”

docs.abstract: Here is the trick: Let your smartphone do the work.
docs.snippet: Here is the trick: Let your smartphone do the work.
docs.lead_paragraph: Do you ever find yourself scrolling madly through your phone’s camera roll, looking for that one fabulous vacation shot you’re describing to a friend — and you can’t find it in the river of 4,000 photos? Or do you want to collect all the pictures of a child, scattered through the years, for a slide show but don’t have time to find them?

headline.main: Organizing Your Unwieldy Photo Collection Is Easier Than You Think
headline.print_headline: How to Organize Your Unwieldy Photo Trove

docs.abstract: The newsletter’s countdown starts today, with #5.
docs.snippet: The newsletter’s countdown starts today, with #5.
docs.lead_paragraph: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive the newsletter each weekday.

headline.main: The Five Most Important Stories of 2018

docs.abstract: The stock market looks rough. Apple shares look rougher. But at least we’re making progress in space!
docs.snippet: The stock market looks rough. Apple shares look rougher. But at least we’re making progress in space!
docs.lead_paragraph: If you’re like me, you aspired to leap into January bright-eyed and ready to break all sorts of personal productivity records. But instead, here we are, scrambling as usual and digging through backlogs of emails that have sat unchecked since the Friday before Christmas.

headline.main: The Week in Business: Who Wanted a Slow Start to the New Year, Anyway?

docs.abstract: Technology publications are asking pointed questions about the online retail company. And Apple had rare, surprising bad news about sales.
docs.snippet: Technology publications are asking pointed questions about the online retail company. And Apple had rare, surprising bad news about sales.
docs.lead_paragraph: Each week, technology reporters and columnists from The New York Times review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Want this newsletter in your inbox? Sign up here.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: Amazon’s Burning Problems
headline.print_headline: A Look at a Retail Giant’s Blind Spots

docs.abstract: Apple’s chief executive has enjoyed enormous success over his seven years running the company, but he’s likely to face tougher times ahead.
docs.snippet: Apple’s chief executive has enjoyed enormous success over his seven years running the company, but he’s likely to face tougher times ahead.
docs.lead_paragraph: Do not pity Timothy D. Cook. He has made hundreds of millions of dollars as Apple’s chief executive. He is regarded as one of business’s best bosses, and runs a company with a beloved brand and $130 billion in cash.

headline.main: 5 Reasons You Wouldn’t Want to Be in Tim Cook’s Shoes Right Now
headline.print_headline: 5 Reasons Apple’s Chief May Face Tougher Times Ahead

docs.abstract: Tech companies have changed the world by building answers to obvious questions — but now the obvious, pressing questions are about them.
docs.snippet: Tech companies have changed the world by building answers to obvious questions — but now the obvious, pressing questions are about them.
docs.lead_paragraph: In start-up lore, no figure is more venerated than the tech-world founder. No mere entrepreneur, the founder is unique, sitting above the categories other people might use to order the society around them. In fact, the personage is cast as a sort of revolutionary, proposing big solutions to questions nobody else is even thinking to ask — less often because the questions are too complicated or obscure than because they’re too obvious, too expansive.

headline.main: Have the Tech Giants Grown Too Powerful? That’s an Easy One
headline.print_headline: Have the Tech Giants Grown Too Powerful? That’s an Easy One
